title: Tulsi Gabbard wants to meet Hillary Clinton face-to-face after 2016 loser called her Russia 'asset'
text:
Tulsi Gabbard said Monday she wants to confront Hillary Clinton after the failed 2016 presidential candidate perpetuated a conspiracy theory that she's a 'Russian asset.'

The 2020 contender was asked by a reporter if she was disappointed that Clinton dropped out of the Most Powerful Women Summit in Washington, D.C., which Gabbard will attend on Tuesday.

'Well, she had something to say about me, and I would have been very happy to have that conversation directly face-to-face with her,' Gabbard said during a campaign stop in Iowa.

Clinton said in a podcast interview released last week that Gabbard is being 'groomed' by Russia to run as a spoiler third-party candidate to take away votes from the Democrat nomination by the Democratic National Committee to take on Donald Trump in 2020.

Gabbard has repeatedly said she has no interest and has ruled-out the potential of running as a third-party candidate should she fail to clinch the Democratic nomination.

Tulsi Gabbard said she would have liked the opportunity to confront Hillary Clinton 'face-to-face' on Tuesday at the Fortune Most Powerful Women Summit in Washington, D.C.

Clinton, who claimed Gabbard is being 'groomed' by Russias, announced last week she would not be attending the summit anymore

NEW: @TulsiGabbard on if she's disappointed she won't be able to say anything in person to @HillaryClinton tmrw at the Most Powerful Women's Summit says "she had something to say about me and I would have been very happy to have that conversation directly face to face with her" pic.twitter.com/ZA0AbkuvUD — Kelly Phares (@kellyfphares) October 22, 2019

Although she did not explicitly say Gabbard's name, it was later confirmed by a spokesperson for Clinton that the candidate she was talking about is the Hawaii representative and active duty Army National Guard officer.

'If the nesting doll fits,' Clinton spokesman Nick Merrill told reporters when asked if the former secretary of state was referring to Gabbard in her interview.

Her comments came as reports emerged accusing Gabbard of being a 'Russia asset' and 'apologize' for Bashar al-Assad – comments Gabbard called 'completely despicable' during last Tuesday's Democratic debates in Ohio.

Both Democratic and Republican politicians, including Trump and fellow 2020 contender Bernie Sanders, have condemned Clinton's comments.

Trump on Monday expressed empathy for Gabbard, saying he had some familiarity with being unfoundedly accused of Russian collaboration.

'I said, wait a minute, it took me two-and-a-half years, I wish [Clinton] would have said that earlier because people... have realized she is crazy. She's crazy,' the president told Fox News' Sean Hannity in an interview that aired Monday.

'She's accusing everyone of being a Russian agent,' Trump also told reporters, referring to Clinton. 'She's not a Russian agent. These people are sick. There's something wrong with them.'

Trump added that he thought Clinton's substance-free accusations against Gabbard ultimately would help his own political chances in 2020.

Sanders also came to her defense.

'Tulsi Gabbard has put her life on the line to defend this country. People can disagree on issues, but it is outrageous for anyone to suggest that Tulsi is a foreign asset,' Sanders tweeted Monday evening, making mention of her overseas deployment.

'Thank you for speaking the truth,' Gabbard said when asked what her reaction was to Sanders' defense.

Reports emerged that Clinton dropped the engagement because former Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen is also attending

Bernie Sanders also came to Gabbard's defense. Gabbard stepped down from her post as vice chairwoman of the DNC and endorsed Sanders in 2016 instead of establishment Democrat Hillary Clinton

He said the attack from Clinton against Gabbard is 'outrageous'

In 2016, Gabbard quit as vice chairwoman of the DNC and endorsed Sanders instead of Clinton in the Democratic primary race. At the time she also accused Democratic party leaders of stifling her freedom of speech and unfairly tipping the scales in favor of Clinton's presidential campaign.

She insisted in a video over the weekend that her decision to support Sanders could be linked to Clinton's 'smear' of her now.

'People warned me in 2016 that my endorsement of Bernie Sanders would be the end of my 'political career' -- they said Clinton would never forget, that she and her rich and powerful friends -- her allies in politics and the media -- will make sure you're destroyed,' Gabbard said in the video posted to her Twitter Sunday.

'If they can falsely portray me as a traitor, then they can do it to anyone -- and in fact, that's exactly the message they want to get across to you,' Gabbard continued.

'If you stand up to Hillary and the party power brokers -- if you stand up to the rich and powerful elite and the war machine, they will destroy you and discredit your message. But, here is the truth: They will not intimidate us. They will not silence us,' she said.

Sanders joined the likes of a handful of other Democratic candidates who have come to Gabbard's defense in the last few days: entrepreneur Andrew Yang, former Rep. Beto O'Rourke and author and spiritual adviser Marianne Williamson.

Clinton also said Gabbard is a 'favorite of the Russians,' likely due to the fact she is a frequent mention in Russian and Kremlin-backed media outlets.

Gabbard suggested that she wants a chance to confront Clinton, but that will not be happening at the Fortune Most Powerful Women Summit this week.

Clinton, who was scheduled to appear at the summit with a trove of other powerful women, said she last week she would no longer be going. Although Merrill cited a scheduling conflict, reports indicate she dropped the engagement because the event would also feature Trump's former Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen.

Gabbard is critical of the Democratic establishment – even though she's running in the Democratic primary. She even floated boycotting the October debates, accusing the Democratic Party of 'rigging' the election and obviously favoring certain candidates during the debates.
description: Tulsi Gabbard said Monday she wants to confront Hillary Clinton after the failed 2016 presidential candidate perpetuated a conspiracy theory that she's a 'Russian asset.'
